title: Hammer time for class actions
text:
“These cases are going to get on, quickly,'' said Hammer J. "Let me say what I want to say ...

“I think all three proceedings should be consolidated. The Ashita Tomi proceedings should proceed and the litigation funders for the other two should be given an option to participate in the funding of Ashita Tomi as to one third each. If the option is not exercised by one, then Ashita Tomi and the other funder will share that one-third.”

The bit in the middle was about too much time and money being wasted by law firms fighting over the same pot of money. (The Hammer was also never going to be happy about any matter taking an hour of his Friday list.)

'Not viabIe': Investor Claim Partner's John Walker.

As it turns out one of the funders, Investor Claim Partner, walked.

"ICP declined principally on the basis that the claim had to include a period of trading in RCR shares which I didn’t consider was viable,'' said ICP chief John Walker this week.

"IMF and Burford are now co-funding it."

Hearsay reckons there is nothing like multiple class actions to make a nonsense of the claim by plaintiff law firms that it's primarily about providing access to justice.

Advertisement

As Bell pointed out, there was an unseemly rush to court registries after the disaster that was AMP at the Hayne royal commission, with five filing. Four ended up at the barrier after Maurice Blackburn took over Slater & Gordon’s claim. The others were Quinn Emanuel. who filed first, Shine and Phi Finney McDonald.

The AMP case has been the catalyst for the courts to say enough. Judges are running a much closer eye over funding deals – no-win, no fee seems to have particular appeal – and when there are competing claims they are prepared to knock heads together.

Cough up

The week’s other major decision in class action land was handed down by federal court judge Michael Lee in the Chandler McLeod-BHP claim.

Lee found the Fair Work Act's costs shield, which exempts parties from the usual obligation to pay costs if they lose, doesn’t apply to litigation funders.

This means that UK funder Augusta Ventures will have to stump up an expected $2.1 million in security of costs before the case proceeds. (For Maurice Blackburn in the AMP litigation it's $5 million.)

Monash University law professor Vince Morabito doesn't concur with those who say it will have a chilling effect on employment claims. He told Hearsay's colleague Hannah Wootton that they are picking up again and funders are increasingly taking out insurance for adverse cost orders anyway.

However, the professor suspects the effect of rising premiums on the bottom line of funders might prompt them to ask courts for a greater proportion of settlements, which means less money for class members.

Judgment day in Myer case

It's been a blight on the class actions landscape that no shareholder claim has ever proceeded to judgment.

That's about to change with word coming through this week that Justice Jonathan Beach is putting the finishing touches on his reasons in the TPT Patrol v Myer litigation and will deliver his judgment on October 24.

The case concerns the crux of most shareholder claims – an alleged failure to disclose information to the market which would have had a "material" effect on the share price.

Beach reserved his judgment in December. He took the case on soon after finishing the Westpac bank bill swap case, so he’s becoming a glutton for punishment.
description: Hearsay: Praise for Justice David Hammerschlag in a big week for class actions.
